itemdesc-cookedveggie-*-partbaked: Could use a bit more baking...
itemdesc-cookedveggie-*-charred: It's overcooked, but at least it lasts longer...
itemdesc-dryfruit-*: Baked into a highly preservable state.
itemdesc-meatnugget-*-smashed: Cut it up into chunks or cook it as-is!
itemdesc-meatnugget-*-cured: Chopped cured meat. Good in meals.
itemdesc-meatnugget-*-cookedpartbaked: Could use a little more cooking...
itemdesc-meatnugget-*-tenderpartbaked: Could use a little more cooking...
game:itemdesc-fishsauce: Umami! Add to sushi, stews, or au gratin for richer flavor.
itemdesc-breadcrumbs-*: Bread, but powdery. Great for thickening stews and soups.
itemdesc-acornbreadcrumbs-*: Nutty bread, but powdery. Great for thickening stews and soups.
itemdesc-breadedmeatnugget-*-syruppartba: Sweet, slightly crunchy meat. Cook it more!
itemdesc-breadedmeatnugget-*-syrupcharre: Sweet, chewy crunchy meat. Could be tastier.
itemdesc-acornbreadedmeatnugget-*-partba: Slightly crunchy and nutty - cook it more!
itemdesc-acornbreadedmeatnugget-*-charre: Really crunchy and overly chewy. Still tastes earthy.
itemdesc-acornbreadedmeatnugget-*-syrupp: Sweet, slightly crunchy meat. Cook it more!
itemdesc-acornbreadedmeatnugget-*-syrups: Sweet, crunchy meat! Has rich flavor.
itemdesc-acornbreadedmeatnugget-*-syrupc: Sweet, chewy crunchy meat. Tastes rich, but tough.
itemdesc-breadedfishnugget-*-charred: Super crunchy fish! Perhaps too crunchy?
itemdesc-acornbreadedfishnugget-charred: Super crunchy fish! Earthy and delicious.
itemdesc-acornbreadedfishnugget-syruppar: Sweet, crunchy fish! Nutty and delicious!
itemdesc-acornbreadedfishnugget-syrups: Sweet, crunchy fish! Nutty and delicious!
itemdesc-acornbreadedfishnugget-syrupcha: Sweet, crunchy fish! Nutty and delicious!
itemdesc-hardtack-*-raw: Salty, rough dough. Ready to bake.
itemdesc-hardtack-*-bake1: Tough crackers that keep for years.
itemdesc-hardtack-*-bake2: Twice-baked crackers that are completely flavorless.
itemdesc-hardtack-*-bake3: Thrice-baked crackers. A sharp hazard to yourself and others.
itemdesc-acornhardtack-*-bake1: Tough, earthy crackers that keep for years.
itemdesc-acornhardtack-*-bake2: Twice-baked crackers that are completely flavorless.
itemdesc-acornhardtack-*-bake3: Thrice-baked crackers. A sharp hazard to yourself and others.
expandedfoodsguide-text:
Expanded Foods: Chef's Cookbook
Getting started.

Documentation on this mod can be found here.
Updated versions can be found here.

Introduction
This mod adds a wide variety of uses for food that will make your cooking experience more in-depth. It also interacts with the mods Acorns, Alchemy, Braziers, More Animals, Primitive Survival, SuperFuel, and Wildcraft for even more recipes. Acorns, Primitive Survival, and Wildcraft are recommended - Wild Farming is also highly recommended, since without it you cannot grow seaweed.
This mod includes the ability to make bushmeat meals, vinegar and salt. Delete those mods if you are using this one.

Syntax
To eliminate confusion, certain vocabulary will be defined here. When the Expanded Foods guides use these words, they are in a direct and specific manner.

Bake - Place an item in a hot clay oven.
Boil - Place the items in a Saucepan or Cauldron on a hot firepit.
Cook - Place an item in a firepit's upper slot.
Dry Age - Place the item on a Meat Rack by right-clicking, then wait for it to dry age.
Knead - Place items in the top 6 slots of the Mixing Bowl and right-click to output an item.
Mix - Place a cooking pot in the lower-left slot of a Mixing Bowl, then add food to the top 6 slots and right-click to output a meal.
Press - Place a stack of items in the Fruit Press and right-click to begin pressing.

NEW COOKING BLOCKS

Bottles
Made from clay or glass, bottles are capable of holding liquids in the same manner as bowls and can be placed in the world or on shelves or bottle racks. Used for drizzling syrups or sauces on food via the mixing bowl, fermenting drinks, or simply drinking.
Meat Rack
Sausage or raw meat (but not fish) can be Dried on a meat rack. This process ages the meat and boosts its nutritional value. Raw aged meat needs to have the exterior cut away before cooking.
All forms of meat can be Cooked or Baked.
Mixing Bowl
Vital for creating many Expanded Foods. Can take 6 slots of food or liquid, then Knead it together into a new item. Placing a pot into it allows you to Mix certain meals, such as salads. It can be mechanically powered by connecting an axle to the top or bottom of the block.
In addition to Expanded Foods, it can also Knead regular bread and hardtack dough.
The mixing bowl can be locked with CTRL + Right Click on the bowl. When locked, it will only accept the ingredients that were in it, and in those specific slots. It cannot automatically accept liquids.
Saucepan
Functions somewhat similarly to a bucket, but you can place it onto a firepit to Boil the liquids inside, turning sap and juice into syrup. In order to Boil something in the saucepan, it must be placed into its slots. It is capable of turning some solids, such as bones, into liquids, and turning some liquids, such as water, into solids. Press CTRL + SHIFT + Right Click to place a lid on it, slightly increasing the lifespan of liquids within.
Cauldron
The cauldron is a larger version of the saucepan and is also used to Boil liquids. It is created by pouring liquid metal into a clay cauldron mold. You can also place a lid on the cauldron, but it is more effective than the saucepan's lid.
Spile
Jam this into a tree and place a bucket or saucepan beneath it to collect sap from the tree during certain times of the year.
Fresh Resin can be collected in March through November.
Maple Sap can be collected in January, February, and March.
Birch Sap can be collected in April, May, and June.

NEW COOKING ITEMS

Rolling Pin
Carved from logs or smithed, rolling pins can be used to flatten foods such as meat and pasta dough. They are also a weak weapon.

BASIC FOOD LIST

Boiled Eggs
Boil 1 egg and 1 portion of water. Can be used in salads and cold pasta meals.
Pickled Eggs
Seal eggs and vinegar in a barrel at a 1:1 ratio. Can be used in salads and cold pasta meals.
Bread Crumbs
You can tear a loaf of bread up in the Crafting Grid or place it in a quern to make bread crumbs out of it. When used in meals, a single portion of bread crumbs gives as much nutrition as an entire loaf of bread.
Dehydrated Fruit
After juicing fruit, place the mash into the crafting grid to separate into portions that dry over time into dried fruit. Dehydrated fruit can be added to any meal that accepts fruit
Dried Fruit
Bake fruit to preserve them, or dry dehydrated berries. Dried fruit can be added to any meal that accepts fruit.
Hardtack
Knead 1 flour, 0.1 liters of water, and 1 handful of salt. Eggs and Herbs optional. Once Baked, it can be Baked up to 3 more times to crush the moisture and flavor out of it and make it last longer.
Meat Variants
Hit some meat with a stone or hammer to produce a smashed version of that meat. Slice the tenderized meat up with a knife or cleaver to make meat nuggets. This can be done with fish as well, and can be used in any meals that allow regular meat. You can also hang meat from a meat rack to Dry Age it, which needs to have the outside cut off before cooking.
Salt
Seal 1 liter of water or brine in a barrel to make a bit of salt. Salt now heals 0.5-1 HP when used in food. You can also Boil 1 liter of water to reduce it into salt.
Vinegar
Can be made by sealing fresh berries in a barrel for 28 days, or by letting wine rot instead of cure. If sealed with vinegar as well, it takes a fraction of the time.
Vegetable Variants
Cook or Bake veggies to boost its nutrition and reduce its shelf life. Great way to extend the life of veggies that are about to rot. Veggies and mushrooms can also be chopped with a knife or cleaver to make them easier to eat, and chopped mushrooms can be eaten normally.
expandedfoodsguide2-text:
Cooking 102 - Expanded Foods
Cuisine for the discerning palate.

Documentation on this mod can be found here.
Updated versions can be found here.

EXPANDED FOOD LIST

All Expanded Foods are Kneaded in a Mixing Bowl.

Bread
0.1 L of water OR milk OR pasteurized milk OR soy milk OR broth
1 bag of flour
0.1 L of Food Oil or Lard (optional)
0.1 L Bread Starter (optional)
Bake, Cook, or use as pie crust. Once Baked or Cooked, Knead 0.1 L of syrup, honey, peanut butter, or peanut sauce in the mixing bowl.
Fruit Bread
1 ball of dough
1 fruits or pumpkin slices in up to 5 slots
Fruit, birch, maple, or honey gelatin (optional)
Once Baked or Cooked, Knead 0.1 L of syrup, honey, peanut butter, or peanut sauce in the mixing bowl.
Soft Dough
0.1 L of water OR milk OR pasteurized milk OR soy milk OR broth
1 bag of flour
1 egg
0.1 L of Food Oil or Lard (optional)
Yeast Starter (optional)
Bake, Cook, or use as pie crust.
Muffin
1 ball of soft dough
1 fruits or dried fruits or pumpkin slices in up to 5 slots
1 portion of fruit, birch, maple, or honey gelatin (optional)
Once Baked or Cooked, Knead 0.1 L of syrup, honey, peanut butter, or peanut sauce in the mixing bowl.
Gelatin
Boil 1 liter of bone broth per 1 bone to make 0.25 L of pre-gelatin. Boil 0.1 liters of pre-gelatin, 1 bone, and 1 liter of water to make raw gelatin.
Raw Gelatin can be Boiled with 1 liter of water to make plain gelatin, and 0.1 liter of juice or sauce can be added to make something more flavorful. If you are using syrup, then you will need 2 liters of water, each in a different slot of the saucepan.
Can be used in pies.
Pasta Dough
1 bag of flour
1 egg
Once dough is Kneaded, smash until flat with a hammer or rolling pin and cut into noodles with a knife or cleaver. Noodles can be used in meals or Boiled in a saucepan with 1 liter of water to eat by itself.
Breaded Food
1 egg OR 0.1 liters of honey OR food oil OR birch syrup OR maple syrup OR lard
1 handful of bread crumbs
1 bag of flour
1 handful of smashed meat or meat nuggets OR 1 vegetable/chopped handful of vegetables OR 1 handful of rice grain OR 1 slice of cheese OR 1 boiled egg.
Salt (optional)
When you have breaded your food, you can Knead it with 0.1 L of food oil or lard to 'deep fry' it, or you can Boil it with 0.1 L of food oil or lard. Once Cooked, Baked, or Boiled, Knead 0.1 L of honey, soy sauce, fish sauce, birch syrup, maple syrup, peanut butter, or peanut sauce in the mixing bowl.
Can be used in salads or cold pasta meals.
Dumplings
1 handful of Soft Dough
1 handful of meat nuggets OR chopped veggies OR soybeans (optional)
Salt (optional)
Can be used in stews and soups, Cooked or Baked.
Pemmican
1 handful of animal fat OR 0.1 L of lard
1 fruit in 3 slots
1 handful of meat nuggets in 2 slots
Salt (optional, replaces fruit)
Cook or Bake.
Sausage
1 handful of animal fat OR 0.1 L of lard
1 handful of meat nuggets
Cheddar or Blue cheese (optional)
Salt (optional)
Can be hung on a meat rack to Dry it before cooking. Usable in pies, meat stews, au gratin, and pilaf. Cooked sausage can be used in salads.
Stuffed Pepper
1 bellpepper
1 handful of meat nuggets OR 1 chopped handful of vegetables OR 1 handful of pickled cabbage/bellpeppers OR 1 handful of grain OR 1 portion of cheese OR 1 boiled egg OR 1 handful of dehydrated/dried fruit OR 1 sausage link.
1 egg OR 0.1 L of honey OR food oil OR birch syrup OR maple syrup OR lard (breading optional)
1 handful of bread crumbs (breading optional)
1 bag of flour (breading optional)
Salt (optional)
When you have breaded your pepper, you can Knead it with 0.1 L of food oil or lard to 'deep fry' it, or you can Boil it with 0.1 L of food oil or lard. Once Cooked, Baked, or Boiled, Knead 0.1 L of honey, soy sauce, fish sauce, birch syrup, maple syrup, peanut butter, or peanut sauce in the mixing bowl.
Sushi
1 sheet of dried seaweed
1 handful of rice grain
1 handful of chopped veggies, soybeans, or sauerkraut (optional)
Salt (optional)
Knead 0.1 L of honey, soy sauce, fish sauce, birch syrup, maple syrup, or peanut sauce in the mixing bowl after creating the sushi roll.
Yogurt
In a saucepan, Boil milk until it is pasteurized. Seal 1 liter of curdled milk and 4 handfuls of non-dried fruits in a barrel for 24 hours to create 0.25 L of yogurt starter.
Knead 0.1 L of pasteurized milk with 0.1 L of yogurt starter to create 0.2 L of fermented yogurt. Seal it in a barrel or bottle until it becomes plain yogurt. Knead with 0.1 L of syrup or honey to make flavored yogurt.
Candy
0.1 L of honey OR syrup OR peanut butter
0.1 L of peanut paste OR sunflower grain
Salt (optional)
Knead in the mixing bowl.
Gozinaki
3 handfuls of acorns OR 1 handful of peanuts (regular, cooked, or kernels) in 1 slot
1 portion of honey
Salt (optional)
Knead ingredients in the mixing bowl, then Bake. Once baked, add honey, syrup, peanut butter, or peanut sauce to the mixing bowl and Knead with gozinaki for a real treat.
expandedfoodsguide3-text:
Cooking 103 - Expanded Meals
The culinary arts, explained.

Documentation on this mod can be found here.
Updated versions can be found here.

Introduction
If you want to make the most out of your culinary experience, then learn how to make the following meals. NOTE: ALL MEALS USING A COOKING POT REQUIRE EXACT PORTIONS!

COOKING POT MEALS

Au Gratin (Cooking Meal)
In a cooking pot, Cook 0.1 L of milk and 1 slice of cheese. You can add vegetables, meat, sausage, eggs, bread crumbs, or more cheese to it. You can also add 0.1 L of fish sauce, soy sauce, food oil, or lard before you start cooking.
Cold Pasta (Mixing Meal)
Knead pasta dough, smash it flat, then chop it into noodles and Boil it in a saucepan with water to cook the noodles. Place a cooking pot in the lower-left slot of the mixing bowl, then Mix 1 portion of cooked pasta noodles. You can add cheese, vegetables, meat, sausage, or eggs to it (even fried kinds). You can also add 0.1 L of fish sauce, soy sauce, food oil, or lard before you start mixing.
Hot Pasta (Cooking Meal)
In a cooking pot, Cook 1 portion of pasta noodles and 1 liter of water, vegetable juice, or broth. You can add cheese, vegetables, meat, sausage, or eggs to it. You can also add 0.1 L of fish sauce, soy sauce, food oil, or lard before you start cooking.
Pilaf (Cooking Meal)
In a cooking pot, Cook 1 portion of rice grain and 1 portion of soy beans OR chopped meat/vegetables. You can add vegetables, meat, sausage, or eggs to it. You can also add 0.1 L of fish sauce, soy sauce, food oil, or lard before you start cooking.
Salad (Mixing Meal)
Place a cooking pot in the mixing bowl's lower slot to get it ready, then Mix together 2 portions of chopped vegetables or soybeans. You can add more veggies, fried veggies, boiled eggs, cooked sausages, cooked meat, fried meat, fruit, dehydrated/dry fruit, cheese, flax/sunflower grain, and salt. You can also add 0.1 L of fish sauce, soy sauce, food oil, fruit syrup, or vinegar before mixing.
Yogurt Meal (Mixing Meal)
Place a cooking pot in the mixing bowl's lower slot to get it ready, then put a 0.5 L of yogurt in it and at least one other item, then Mix. You can add fruit and peanuts to it. You can also add 0.1 L of honey, tree syrup, fruit syrup, or gelatin before mixing.
Additions to Meat Stew
Meat stews also accept dumplings, bread crumbs, and dehydrated/dried berries. You can also add 0.1 L of fish sauce, soy sauce, food oil, wine, or lard before you start cooking, or 1 L of broth.
Additions to Porridge
Porridge also accepts dehydrated/dried berries. You can also add 0.1 L of milk, maple syrup, birch syrup, fruit syrup, or lard before cooking.
Additions to Soup
Soup now accepts vegetable juice or broth instead of water. You may also add dumplings, bread crumbs, and amaranth/rice/spelt grain.
Additions to Veggie Stew
Veggie stews also accept dumplings and bread crumbs. You can also add 0.1 L of fish sauce, soy sauce, food oil, lard, or alcohol before cooking, or 1 L of broth.
Additions to Scrambled Eggs
Scrambled Eggs now accept all kinds of milk; all vegetables, meat nuggets and sausage. You can also add 0.1 L of fish sauce, soy sauce, food oil, and lard before cooking.
expandedfoodsguide4-text:
Cooking 104 - Juicing
How do I make wine?

Documentation on this mod can be found here.
Updated versions can be found here.

Introduction
Squeezing the liquids out of something is a great way to expand your palate with new options. Here are all of the new liquids and how they can be made.

LIQUIDS LIST

Broth
In meals: Bone/Fish Broth - 100 Protein Satiety; 1 HP
Meat Broth - 125 Protein Satiety; 1 HP
Vegetable Broth - 100 Vegetable Satiety; 1 HP
Boil bones/part-baked meat/part-baked veggies or mushrooms/whole fish and water in a saucepan at a ratio of 1 item per 1 liter of water.
Bread Starter
In bread: 25 Grain Satiety; 1.5 HP
Place dried berries/pineapple slices and water in a barrel at a ratio of 6 handfuls of berries/slices per liter of water. Seal for 4 days to make yeast water, then Mix in a mixing bowl with 1 bag of flour and 1 handful of salt to make Wild Yeast Starter. Mix 1 liters of yeast starter, 1 liter of water in 2 slots, and 1 bag of flour in 2 slots together in the mixing bowl to create more yeast starter, allowing you to maintain it.
Food Oil
In meals or expanded foods: 64 Vegetable Satiety; 0.5 HP
Place flax grains, rice grains, seeds, soy beans, or olives into a fruit press and Press.
Fruit Syrup
In meals or expanded foods: 120 Fruit Satiety; 1 or 2 HP
When drank: 800 Fruit Satiety; 1 or 2 HP per liter
Boil fruit juice in a saucepan; 4 juice reduces to 1 syrup. For cactus syrup, Boil 1 liter of water and 1 portion of saguaro fruit in a saucepan. Heals 2 HP.
Lard
In meals or expanded foods: 160 Protein Satiety; 1 HP
Boil 1 handful of fat in the saucepan with 0.2 L of water.
Soy Sauce
In meals or expanded foods: 64 Protein Satiety; 1 HP
In a barrel, soak soybeans in water, one liter of water per soybean portion. Once fully soaked, Cook over a firepit and grind in a quern to make roasted soybean powder. Mix this powder with any grain in a mixing bowl or crafting grid to make soy sauce culture and soak in 1 liter of brine. Once the final soak is done, Press the soy slurry in a fruit press to retrieve soy sauce.
Soy Milk
In meals or expanded foods: 12 Dairy Satiety; 0.1 HP
When drank: 75 Dairy Satiety; 1 HP per liter
In a barrel, soak soybeans in water, one liter of water per soybean portion. Once fully soaked, place in the crafting grid to de-shell the soybeans, then mix with 1 liter of water in the crafting grid. Grind mixture in a quern to make a blended soybean mixture. Press to make raw soy milk, then Boil to make edible soy milk.
Tree Sap
When drank (birch sap only): 160 Fruit Satiety per liter
Jam a spile into a birch/maple tree and place a bucket or saucepan underneath to collect... in certain months. Check Cooking 101 for details.
Tree Syrup
In meals or expanded foods: 96 Fruit Satiety; 1 HP
When drank: 640 Fruit Satiety; 1 HP per liter
Boil tree sap in a saucepan; 4 sap reduces to 1 syrup.
Vegetable Juice
In meals: 300 Vegetable Satiety
When drank: 200 Vegetable Satiety per liter
Place vegetables into a fruit press and Press.
Vinegar
In meals: 150 Fruit Satiety; 0.5 HP
Seal wine or spirits in a barrel to let it ferment, or place 3 berries/pineapple slices and vinegar in a barrel to make it quickly. Takes 2 weeks in a barrel and 1 week the quick way.
Peanut Butter
In meals or expanded foods: 320 Protein Satiety; 60 Vegetable Satiety; 40-120 Fruit Satiety (optional)
Break peanuts apart in the Crafting Grid to get skins and kernels, then Grind kernels into Peanut Paste. Knead equal portions of peanut paste and food oil to make peanut butter. Honey OR syrup, and salt may also be used when kneading.
Peanut Sauce
In meals or expanded foods: 220 Protein Satiety; 40-120 Fruit Satiety
Break peanuts apart in the Crafting Grid to get skins and kernels, then Grind kernels into Peanut Paste. Knead equal portions of peanut paste, soy sauce, honey or syrup, and water to make peanut sauce. Salt may also be used when kneading... 10 salt per 0.1 L of liquid.
Fish Sauce (Primitive Survival Only)
In meals: 50 Protein Satiety
Seal fish in a barrel or Press them in a fruit press.
Bass/Bluegill require 1 liter of water per fish.
Arctic Char/Carp/Perch/Pike/Trout require 2 liters of water per fish.
Catfish require 3 liters of water per fish.
Fish fillets can be used, but require 3 fillets per liter of water.

These categories apply to the fruit press as well, but you need at least 1 Catfish, 2 Arctic Char/Carp/Perch/Pike/Trout, 4 Bass/Bluegill, or 6 fish fillets.

ALCOHOL CHANGES
All alcohol in the base game can now spoil into vinegar if left out in the open long enough. Seal them into a cauldron or store them in bottles and they will cure, becoming finer with age. If juice is stored in this way, it will eventually cure into cider.
expandedfoodsguide5-text:
Cooking 105 - Compatibility
These mods let me make WHAT?

Documentation on this mod can be found here.
Updated versions can be found here.

Introduction
Expanded Foods has new recipes utilizing aspects from the following mods: Acorns, Alchemy, Braziers, Braziers, More Animals, Primitive Survival, SuperFuel, and Wildcraft. This section details how to make these foods.

ACORNS

Handful of Acorns
Place dry leached acorns onto your crafting grid to split them into managable portions.
Acorns may be added to Meat Stews, Porridge, Vegetable Stews, Au Gratin, Pilaf, Salads, and Yogurt. They are interchangable with peanuts in recipes & foods. When making Gozinaki, use 3 handfuls of acorns instead of 1 handful of peanuts.
Vegetarian Trail Mix
3 handfuls of acorns OR 1 handful of peanuts (regular, cooked, or kernels) in 1 slot
1 handful of soybeans
3 handfuls of dried fruit in 1 slot
1 slice of Cheddar or Blue cheese
Kneaded in the mixing bowl. There are 4 types of vegetarian trail mix - Beany, Cheesy, Fruity, and Nutty. To make that variant, add 1 or 2 more slots of any of the previous ingredients (ie. 3 handfuls of acorns/ 1 handful of peanuts into 1 or 2 more slots to make Nutty trail mix).

All other Acorns additions simply involve adding Acorn Flour to a recipe that uses flour, or using acorn crumbs in place of regular crumbs.

PRIMITIVE SURVIVAL

Fish Sauce
See Cooking 103 for details.
Breaded Fish
1 egg OR 0.1 L of honey OR food oil OR birch syrup OR maple syrup OR lard
1 handful of bread crumbs
1 smashed fish fillet or handful of fish nuggets
Salt (optional)
When you have breaded your food, you can Knead it with 0.1 L of food oil or lard in the mixing bowl to 'deep fry' it. Once Cooked or Baked, Knead 0.1 L of honey, soy sauce, fish sauce, birch syrup, or maple syrup in the mixing bowl.
Fish Dumplings
1 handful of Soft Dough
1 handful of fish nuggets
Salt (optional)
Knead in the mixing bowl. Can be used in stews and soups.
Fish Pemmican
1 handful of animal fat OR 0.1 L of lard
1 fruit in 3 slots
1 handful of fish and/or meat nuggets in 2 slots
Salt (optional, replaces fruit)
Sushi
1 sheet of dried seaweed
1 handful of rice grain
1 handful of fish nuggets
1 handful of chopped veggies, soybeans, or sauerkraut (optional)
Salt (optional)
Knead 0.1 L of honey, soy sauce, fish sauce, birch syrup, or maple syrup for more flavor.
Trail Mix
3 handfuls of acorns in 1 slot
4 sticks of jerky in 1 slot
3 handfuls of dried fruit in 1 slot
1 slice of Cheddar or Blue cheese
Kneaded in the mixing bowl. There are 4 types of trail mix - Cheesy, Fruity, Meaty, and Nutty. To make that variant, add 1 or 2 more slots of any of the previous ingredients (ie. 4 sticks of jerky into 1 or 2 more slots to make Meaty trail mix).

NOTE

Crab meat is interchangable with fish in all recipes.
Snake meat is interchangable with chicken in all recipes.

WILDCRAFT

Herbs from Wildcraft can be added to most foods added by this mod, including all recipes.
Breaded Fish/Meat
Add bundle of herbs
Dumplings
Add bundle of herb
Fish/Meat Pemmican
Bundle of herbs replaces 1 fruit
Sausage
Add bundle of herbs
Sushi
Add bundle of herbs
Gozinaki
Add bundle of herbs
Herbal Bread
1 ball of dough
1 herb in up to 5 slots
Once Baked or Cooked, add birch/maple syrup or honey in the mixing bowl.

Fruits from Wildcraft may be used in exactly the same manner as regular fruits.
Miner's lettuce can be used in any recipe that chopped cabbage is usable in.

BRAZIERS

Food Oil and Lard can be used to create Braziers.

MORE ANIMALS

Weird bird eggs can be used in place of chicken eggs.

SUPERFUELS

Food Oil and Lard can be used to create Fire Logs.
itemdesc-choppedvegetable-flyagaric: Maybe this wouldn't hurt if you cooked it?
itemdesc-choppedvegetable-*: Chopped away all the inedible bits!
itemdesc-cookedchoppedvegetable-*-partba: Could use a bit more baking...
itemdesc-cookedchoppedvegetable-*-charre: It's overcooked, but at least it lasts longer...
itemdesc-berrybread-dough: Sweet fruit dough. Handle with care.
itemdesc-berrybread-partbaked: It's a bit chewy, but still sweet!
itemdesc-berrybread-cooked: Sweet fruit bread. Good for breakfast.
itemdesc-berrybread-charred: A tough, sweet treat that lasts a long time.
itemdesc-berrybread-syruppartbaked: An ultra-sweet treat that needs more heat!
itemdesc-berrybread-syrupcharred: Who cares if it's burnt? It's delicious!
itemdesc-acornberrybread-dough: Sweet fruit acorn dough. Handle with care.
itemdesc-acornberrybread-partbaked: It's a bit chewy and nutty, but still sweet!
itemdesc-acornberrybread-cooked: Sweet fruit acorn bread. Good for breakfast.
itemdesc-acornberrybread-charred: A tough, nutty treat that lasts a long time.
itemdesc-acornberrybread-syruppartbaked: An ultra-sweet nutty treat that needs more heat!
itemdesc-acornberrybread-syrup: Overly sweet fruit bread. Nutty and rich!
itemdesc-acornberrybread-syrupcharred: Who cares if it's burnt? It's nutty and delicious!
itemdesc-plaindoughball-ball: A soft, sticky variety of dough.
itemdesc-plaindoughball-partbaked: Soft and somewhat gummy balls of bread.
itemdesc-plaindoughball-bread: Soft and fluffy balls of bread.
itemdesc-plaindoughball-charred: Hard balls of bread. Still somewhat fluffy.
itemdesc-acorndoughball-ball: A soft, sticky variety of nutty dough.
itemdesc-acorndoughball-partbaked: Soft and somewhat gummy balls of nutty bread.
itemdesc-acorndoughball-bread: Soft and fluffy balls of bread. Nutty!
itemdesc-acorndoughball-charred: Hard balls of nutty bread. Still somewhat fluffy.
itemdesc-pemmican-partbaked: It's meaty and gummy. Odd, but not bad.
itemdesc-pemmican-cooked: Nice, warm pemmican with a meaty flavor.
itemdesc-pemmican-charred: At least it keeps for a long time...
itemdesc-pemmican-raw: An edible ball of pemmican that could use some heating up.
itemdesc-fishpemmican-partbaked: It's fishy and gummy. Odd, but not bad.
itemdesc-fishpemmican-cooked: Nice, warm pemmican with a fishy flavor.
itemdesc-fishpemmican-charred: At least it keeps for a long time...
itemdesc-fishpemmican-raw: An edible ball of fishy pemmican that could use some heating up.
itemdesc-muffin-dough: Soft fruit dough. Handle with love.
itemdesc-muffin-partbaked: This fruit muffin's a bit soft, but still yummy.
itemdesc-muffin-cooked: A fluffy and delicious fruit muffin!
itemdesc-muffin-charred: A tough fruit muffin - the fruit tastes burnt!
itemdesc-muffin-syrupcharred: Syrup will hide the charred flavor...
itemdesc-acornmuffin-dough: Soft acorn fruit dough. Handle with love.
itemdesc-acornmuffin-partbaked: This acorn fruit muffin's a bit soft, but still yummy.
itemdesc-acornmuffin-cooked: A fluffy and delicious acorn fruit muffin!
itemdesc-acornmuffin-charred: Burning it really brings out the nutty flavor.
itemdesc-acornmuffin-syrupcharred: Syrup will hide the charred flavor...
itemdesc-dumpling-raw: Hearty, filling dumplings. Good in meals.
itemdesc-acorndumpling-raw: Hearty, filling dumplings with an earthy flavor. Good in meals.
itemdesc-acorndumpling-partbaked: These earthy dumplings are a bit undercooked...
itemdesc-acorndumpling-cooked: Hearty, filling dumplings with an earthy flavor.
itemdesc-soysauce: Savory soy sauce, good in stews or on sushi!
itemdesc-driedseaweed-mash: Use your hands to shape into sheets.
itemdesc-driedseaweed-edible: Used with raw fish and rice to make sushi.
itemdesc-sushi-noveggie-nooil: A naked sushi roll. Come on, spice it up!
itemdesc-sushi-*-oil: The best sushi roll imaginable. Heavenly!
itemdesc-sushi-noveggie-honey: A sushi roll drizzled with honey. Sweet!
itemdesc-sushi-*-honey: The best sushi roll imaginable. Heavenly!
itemdesc-sushi-noveggie-peanut: A sushi roll drizzled with peanut sauce. Sweet!
itemdesc-sushi-*-peanut: The best sushi roll imaginable. Heavenly!

itemdesc-sushiveg-noveggie-peanut: A sushi roll drizzled with peanut sauce. Sweet!

itemdesc-sausage-*-raw: Hang it up to dry or cook it fast!
itemdesc-sausage-*-charred: It's a bit chewier than you'd like.
itemdesc-sausageherb-*-raw: Hang it up to dry or cook it fast!
itemdesc-sausageherb-*-cooked: Juicy and delicious, bursting with flavor!
itemdesc-sausageherb-*-charred: It's a bit chewier than you'd like.
itemdesc-sausageherb-*-driedcooked: You've never had meat so tasty!
itemdesc-sausagefish-*-raw: Hang it up to dry or cook it fast!
itemdesc-sausagefishherb-*-raw: Hang it up to dry or cook it fast!
itemdesc-sausagefishherb-*-cooked: Juicy and delicious, bursting with flavor!
itemdesc-sausagefishherb-*-driedcooked: You've never had meat so tasty!
itemdesc-birchsapportion: Boil into syrup or drink it on its own!
itemdesc-maplesapportion: This would make some great syrup...
itemdesc-foodoilportion-*: Great for cooking or lubricating mechanics!
itemdesc-fishsauce: Umami! Good in almost any meal.
itemdesc-treesyrupportion-*: Thick, sweet, good on treats or as batter!
itemdesc-brothportion-bone: Yummy bone juice that thickens stews and soups right up!
itemdesc-soyprep-soaked: Cook in a firepit to roast the beans (for soy sauce) or de-shell in the crafting grid (for soy milk).
itemdesc-soyprep-roasted: Grind in a quern to powderize.
itemdesc-soyprep-cultured: Seal in a barrel with 1 L of brine.
itemdesc-soyprep-slurry: Squeeze in a fruit press to make soy sauce.
itemdesc-agedmeat-*-normal: Slice off the outside to get to the good part!
itemdesc-agedmeat-*-cut: Dry aged meat, tender and delicious.
itemdesc-agedmeat-*-tenderpartbaked: Could use a little more cooking...
itemdesc-agedmeat-*-tender: It falls apart at the touch!
itemdesc-agedmeat-*-meatballpartbaked: Could use a little more cooking...
itemdesc-agedmeat-*-meatball: It falls apart at the touch!
itemdesc-gelatin-liquid: Congealed bone juice. Cook it with bones to solidify it more.
itemdesc-gelatin-raw: Mostly solid gelatin that should be cooked with water and other liquids.
itemdesc-lard: A good replacement for fat or food oil.
itemdesc-breadedball-*-cooked: A crunchy, delicious fried ball of... something!
itemdesc-breadedball-*-charred: A tough, crunchy ball of... something.
itemdesc-breadedvegetable-*-cooked: A fried vegetable. Soft on the inside!
itemdesc-breadedvegetable-*-charred: An overly fried vegetable, crunchy and mushy.
itemdesc-pasteurizedmilkportion: Boiled milk. Mix with a yogurt starter.
itemdesc-yogurt-starter: Sour curds. Mix with pasteurized milk.
itemdesc-yogurt-ferment: Seal in a bottle or barrel to turn into edible yogurt.
itemdesc-gozinakiherb-*: A fantastically nutty dessert, with fragrant undertones.
itemdesc-softresin: Needs 700-1000 mL and 2 weeks to cure into resin.
itemdesc-tea-herb: A healthy drink that soothes the spirit.
itemdesc-herbalbread-dough: Dough that's been infused with delicious herbs.
itemdesc-herbalbread-partbaked: Smells nice, but it's a bit too soft.
itemdesc-herbalbread-cooked: Fragrant. Best when shared with others.
itemdesc-herbalbread-charred: It's overcooked, but the flavor still comes through.
itemdesc-herbalacornbread-dough: Nutty dough that's been infused with delicious herbs.
itemdesc-herbalacornbread-partbaked: Smells great, but it's a bit too soft.
itemdesc-herbalacornbread-cooked: Fragrant and nutty. Best when shared with others.
itemdesc-herbalacornbread-charred: It's overcooked, but the nutty  flavor still comes through.
itemdesc-herbalacornbread-syruppartbaked: Fragrant, nutty bread drizzled with syrup.
itemdesc-herbalacornbread-syrup: Fragrant, nutty bread drizzled with syrup.
itemdesc-herbalacornbread-syrupcharred: Fragrant, nutty bread drizzled with syrup.
game:itemdesc-bushmeat-partbaked: Could use a little more cooking...
game:itemdesc-poultry-partbaked: Could use a little more cooking...
game:itemdesc-redmeat-partbaked: Could use a little more cooking...
itemdesc-herbalhardtack-*-raw: Salty, rough dough. Smells kinda nice. Ready to bake.
itemdesc-herbalhardtack-*-bake1: Tough herbal crackers that keep for years.
itemdesc-herbalhardtack-*-bake2: Twice-baked herbal crackers that are completely flavorless.
itemdesc-herbalhardtack-*-bake3: Thrice-baked herbal crackers. A sharp hazard to yourself and others.
itemdesc-herbalacornhardtack-*-raw: Salty, rough dough. Smells nutty and herbal.
itemdesc-herbalacornhardtack-*-bake1: Tough, fragrant crackers that keep for years.
itemdesc-herbalacornhardtack-*-bake2: Twice-baked herbal crackers that are completely flavorless.
itemdesc-herbalacornhardtack-*-bake3: Thrice-baked crackers. A sharp herbal hazard to yourself and others.
itemdesc-herbalacornhardtack-*-bake4: It's like eating burnt oak bark...
itemdesc-soyprep-wetshell: Grind in a quern to blend.
itemdesc-soyprep-blended: Squeeze in a fruit press to make raw soy milk.
itemdesc-soymilk-raw: Boil in a saucepan/cauldron to make edible.
itemdesc-wilddryfruit-*: Dried into a highly preservable state.
itemdesc-crabpemmican-partbaked: It's crabby and gummy. Odd, but not bad.
itemdesc-crabpemmican-cooked: Nice, warm pemmican with a crabby flavor.
itemdesc-crabpemmican-charred: At least it keeps for a long time...
itemdesc-crabpemmican-raw: An edible ball of crabby pemmican that could use some heating up.
itemdesc-snakepemmican-partbaked: It's lizardly and flaky. Odd, but not bad.
itemdesc-snakepemmican-cooked: Nice, warm pemmican with a lizardly flavor.
itemdesc-snakepemmican-charred: At least it keeps for a long time...
itemdesc-snakepemmican-raw: An edible ball of lizardly pemmican that could use some heating up.
